Overload.descr:
Calculates the sum of two INTEGER values.
Example: ADD( field1, 20 )
Calculates the sum of two REAL values.

Concatenates two STRING values.
Example: ADD( 'Hello ', 'World' )

Calculates the sum of two TIMESTAMP values.
Example: (add 3 days to current time): ADD( SYSTEM_TIMESTAMP(), TIMESTAMP('0000-01-04', 'yyyy-MM-dd') )
Date duration reference (epoch is 0000-01-01): 1 day = '0000-01-02' 2 days = '0000-01-03' 7 days = '0000-01-08'

Returns the average among all the INTEGER values, or only the DISTINCT values, of the specified field-expression.
Examples: AVG(DISTINCT Size) AVG(ALL Size) AVG(Size)

Returns the average among all the REAL values, or only the DISTINCT values, of the specified field-expression.
Examples: AVG(DISTINCT Size) AVG(ALL Size) AVG(Size)

Calculates the bitwise AND of two values.
Example (test a bit flag against a specific mask): WHERE BIT_AND( Flags, 0x40 ) <> 0

Calculates the bitwise NOT of a value.
Example (test a bit flag against a specific mask): WHERE BIT_AND( Flags, BIT_NOT( 0x40 ) ) <> 0

Calculates the bitwise OR of two values.
Example (test a bit flag against a specific mask): WHERE BIT_AND( Flags, BIT_OR( 0x40, 0x80 ) ) <> 0

Shifts a value left by a specified number of bits.
Example (shift an integer left by 3 bits): BIT_SHL( Value, 3 )

Calculates the bitwise XOR of two values.
Example: BIT_XOR( Code1, EventMask )

Shifts a value right by a specified number of bits.
Example (shift an integer right by 3 bits): BIT_SHR( Value, 3 )

Compares the argument of the CASE statement with the arguments of the WHEN statements, returning the argument of a THEN statement when a match is found. If no match is found, returns the argument of the ELSE statement, or NULL if no ELSE statement is provided.
Syntax: CASE argument WHEN testValue1 THEN replaceValue1 [WHEN testValue2 THEN replaceValue2 ...] [ELSE finalReplaceValue] END
Example (mapping event log type to string): SELECT CASE EventType WHEN 1 THEN 'ERROR' WHEN 2 THEN 'WARNING' WHEN 4 THEN 'INFORMATION' ELSE 'UNKNOWN' END AS MyEventTypeName FROM System

Returns the first non-NULL value among its arguments. All arguments must be of the same type.
Note: This function substitutes the REPLACE_IF_NULL function available in later versions of Log Parser.
Example: COALESCE( NULL, NULL, NULL, 'Value1', 'Value2' ) Returns: Value1

Returns the NetBIOS name of the local computer.
Example: SELECT COMPUTER_NAME()

Returns the number of records, including NULL values.
Example: SELECT COUNT(*) FROM System

Returns the number of records where at least one of the specified field expressions is non-NULL.
DISTINCT can only be used when the query does not make use of the GROUP BY clause.
Example (distinct count): SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT SourceName) FROM System
Example (non-null count): SELECT COUNT(cs-username) FROM ex040528.log
Example (GROUP BY with HAVING): SELECT cs-uri-stem FROM ex040528.log GROUP BY cs-uri-stem HAVING COUNT(*) > 50

Calculates the quotient of two integer values.
Example: DIV( time-taken, 1000 )

Calculates the quotient of two values. Return type depends on the type of the dividend argument.
Example: DIV( time-taken, 1000 )

Calculates e (the Natural logarithm base) raised to the power of the specified argument.
e is approximately 2.71828182845905.
Example: EXP( MyCategory )

Calculates 10 raised to the power of the specified argument.
Example (round to nearest power of 10): SELECT sc-bytes, TO_INT( EXP10( ROUND( LOG10( sc-bytes ) ) ) ) AS PowerOfTen FROM <1>

Returns the file extension portion of a file path.
Example: EXTRACT_EXTENSION( 'C:\MyLogs\Latest\extend1.log' ) Returns: log

Returns the filename portion of a file path. The returned filename includes the file extension.
Example: EXTRACT_FILENAME( 'C:\MyLogs\Latest\extend1.log' ) Returns: extend1.log

Returns the directory path portion of a file path.
Example: EXTRACT_PATH( 'C:\MyLogs\Latest\extend1.log' ) Returns: C:\MyLogs\Latest

Returns a substring beginning at the first character and up to, but not including, the specified instance of the separator.
Negative index values are relative to the end of the string; -1 indicates the last separator.
Example: EXTRACT_PREFIX( 'First-|-Second-|-Third', 1, '-|-' ) Returns: First-|-Second
Example (negative index): EXTRACT_PREFIX( 'First-|-Second-|-Third', -1, '-|-' ) Returns: First-|-Second

Returns a substring beginning after the specified instance of the separator and up to the end of the string.
Negative index values are relative to the beginning of the string; -1 indicates the first separator.
Example: EXTRACT_SUFFIX( 'First-|-Second-|-Third', 0, '-|-' ) Returns: Third
Example (negative index): EXTRACT_SUFFIX( 'First-|-Second-|-Third', -1, '-|-' ) Returns: Second-|-Third

Splits the string into substrings at each separator occurrence, and returns the substring at the specified index.
Default separator is comma (','). Negative index values are relative to the end of the string; -1 indicates the last substring.
Example: EXTRACT_TOKEN( 'First-|-Second-|-Third', 1, '-|-' ) Returns: Second
Example (negative index): EXTRACT_TOKEN( 'First-|-Second-|-Third', -1, '-|-' ) Returns: Third

Parses 'key=value' pairs in the string, returning the value corresponding to the specified key.
Default separator is '&'. Useful for parsing cookie values from IIS log files.
Example: EXTRACT_VALUE( 'FirstKey=FirstVal&SecondKey=SecondVal', 'SecondKey' ) Returns: SecondVal

Returns the integral part of the specified argument. The largest integer less than or equal to the number.
Example: FLOOR( 4.9837 ) Returns: 4.000000

Returns 1 when the row is added by the ROLLUP operator of the GROUP BY clause, or 0 otherwise.
Used to distinguish NULL values returned by ROLLUP from standard NULL values.
Only allowed when GROUP BY contains the ROLLUP operator.
Example: SELECT date, cs-uri-stem, COUNT(*), GROUPING(date) AS GDate, GROUPING(cs-uri-stem) AS GPage FROM ex040528.log GROUP BY date, cs-uri-stem WITH ROLLUP

Calculates the MD5 hash of the content of a file and returns its hexadecimal representation.
Example: HASHMD5_FILE( 'C:\Temp\MyLib.dll' ) Returns: F01D02D6FD63E98BBD68E61AB96165F2

Returns a unique, sequential integer for each distinct value of the argument. Returns the same value for identical strings, different values for different strings.
Useful for grouping records while retaining the order in which values appear in the data.
Example: SELECT SourceName, HASHSEQ( SourceName ) FROM System
Example (group by order of appearance): SELECT c-ip, HASHSEQ(c-ip) FROM <1> ORDER BY HASHSEQ(c-ip) ASC

Specifies a boolean condition that must be satisfied by a group for the group record to be output. Groups that do not satisfy the condition are discarded.
Example: HAVING EventID = 501
Example (complex): HAVING SUM(sc-bytes) > 100000 AND ( COUNT(*) > 1000 OR EXTRACT_EXTENSION(cs-uri-stem) LIKE 'htm' )
Example (with GROUP BY): SELECT SourceName FROM System GROUP BY SourceName HAVING COUNT(*) > 10

Converts the hexadecimal representation of a series of bytes into a string where bytes in the 0x20-0x7F range are converted to ASCII characters.
Bytes outside that range are converted to period ('.').
Example: HEX_TO_ASC( '6566676804707172' ) Returns: efgh.pqr

Converts the hexadecimal representation of a series of bytes into another hexadecimal representation in which bytes are grouped into 16-bit WORDs.
When bigEndian is non-zero, uses big endian byte order. Default is little endian (bigEndian=0).
Example (little endian): HEX_TO_HEX16( '0490A4FEDC880242' ) Returns: 9004 FEA4 88DC 4202
Example (big endian): HEX_TO_HEX16( '0490A4FEDC880242', 1 ) Returns: 0490 A4FE DC88 0242

Converts the hexadecimal representation of a series of bytes into another hexadecimal representation in which bytes are grouped into 32-bit DWORDs.
When bigEndian is non-zero, uses big endian byte order. Default is little endian (bigEndian=0).
Example (little endian): HEX_TO_HEX32( '0490A4FEDC880242' ) Returns: FEA49004 420288DC
Example (big endian): HEX_TO_HEX32( '0490A4FEDC880242', 1 ) Returns: 0490A4FE DC880242

Converts the hexadecimal representation of a series of bytes into another hexadecimal representation in which bytes are grouped into 8-bit octets.
Example: HEX_TO_HEX8( '0490A4FEDC880242' ) Returns: 04 90 A4 FE DC 88 02 42

Converts the hexadecimal representation of an integer into the integer itself.
Only the first 8 bytes of the hexadecimal representation are parsed.
Example: HEX_TO_INT( 'FE08AAD64C' ) Returns: 1091067106892

Converts the hexadecimal representation of a series of bytes into a string where bytes corresponding to printable ASCII characters are converted to the characters themselves.
Non-printable bytes are converted to period ('.').
Example: HEX_TO_PRINT( '656667680D0A70710472' ) Returns: efgh..pq.r

Returns the character position where the first occurrence of a search substring occurs in a string.
Returns NULL if the substring is not found.
Example: INDEX_OF( '192.168.1.100', '.' ) Returns: 3

Returns the current input record number. Input record numbers start from 1.
Example: SELECT SourceName, IN_ROW_NUMBER() FROM System
Example (retrieve one record out of four): SELECT SourceName FROM System WHERE MOD( IN_ROW_NUMBER(), 4 ) = 0

Converts a 32-bit integer into the string representation of an IPV4 address.
Example: INT_TO_IPV4( 3232235876 ) Returns: 192.168.1.100

Converts the string representation of an IPV4 address into a 32-bit integer.
Example: IPV4_TO_INT( '192.168.1.100' ) Returns: 3232235876

Returns the character position where the last occurrence of a search substring occurs in a string.
Returns NULL if the substring is not found.
Example: LAST_INDEX_OF( '192.168.1.100', '.' ) Returns: 9

Calculates the Natural logarithm of the specified argument.
Returns NULL when the argument is less than or equal to zero.
Example: LOG( MyCategory )

Calculates the base-10 logarithm of the specified argument.
Returns NULL when the argument is less than or equal to zero.
Example (round to nearest power of 10): SELECT sc-bytes, TO_INT( EXP10( ROUND( LOG10( sc-bytes ) ) ) ) AS PowerOfTen FROM <1>

Removes whitespace characters from the beginning of a string.
Example: LTRIM( Comment )

Returns the maximum value among all the values of the specified field-expression. NULL values are ignored.
DISTINCT is available for SQL-92 compatibility only. DISTINCT can only be used without a GROUP BY clause.
Example: SELECT MAX(Size) FROM C:\windows\system32\*.* WHERE TO_LOWERCASE(EXTRACT_EXTENSION(Name)) = 'exe'
Example (with GROUP BY): SELECT TO_LOWERCASE( EXTRACT_EXTENSION(cs-uri-stem)) AS PageType, MAX(time-taken) FROM ex031118.log GROUP BY PageType

Returns the minimum value among all the values of the specified field-expression. NULL values are ignored.
DISTINCT is available for SQL-92 compatibility only. DISTINCT can only be used without a GROUP BY clause.
Example: SELECT MIN(Size) FROM C:\windows\system32\*.* WHERE TO_LOWERCASE(EXTRACT_EXTENSION(Name)) = 'exe'
Example (with GROUP BY): SELECT TO_LOWERCASE( EXTRACT_EXTENSION(cs-uri-stem)) AS PageType, MIN(time-taken), MAX(time-taken) FROM ex031118.log GROUP BY PageType

Calculates the remainder of the division of two values. Return type depends on the type of the dividend argument.
Example: MOD( time-taken, 1000 )

Calculates the remainder of the division of two values. Return type depends on the type of the dividend argument.
Example: MOD( time-taken, 1000 )

Calculates the product of two values. Return type depends on the type of the multiplier argument.
Example: MUL( sc-bytes, 1000 )

Calculates the product of two values. Return type depends on the type of the multiplier argument.
Example: MUL( sc-bytes, 1000 )

Returns the current output record number. Output record numbers start from 1.
Cannot appear in WHERE, GROUP BY, or HAVING clauses, and cannot be used as an argument to aggregate functions.
Example: SELECT SourceName, OUT_ROW_NUMBER() FROM System

Returns the ratio of COUNT on a group to COUNT on a hierarchically higher group.
Multiply by 100.0 using MUL to obtain a percentage. Without GROUP BY, always returns 1.0.
Example (percentage per source): SELECT SourceName, MUL(PROPCOUNT(*), 100.0) AS Percent FROM System GROUP BY SourceName
Example (using ON): SELECT EXTRACT_EXTENSION(cs-uri-stem) AS PageType, sc-status, MUL(PROPCOUNT(*) ON (PageType), 100.0) AS Hits FROM ex040528.log GROUP BY PageType, sc-status

Returns the ratio of SUM on a group to SUM on a hierarchically higher group.
Multiply by 100.0 using MUL to obtain a percentage. Without GROUP BY, always returns 1.0.
Example (percentage of bytes per page type): SELECT EXTRACT_EXTENSION(cs-uri-stem) AS PageType, MUL(PROPSUM(sc-bytes), 100.0) AS PercentBytes FROM ex040528.log GROUP BY PageType
Example (using ON): SELECT EXTRACT_EXTENSION(cs-uri-stem) AS PageType, sc-status, MUL(PROPSUM(sc-bytes) ON (PageType), 100.0) AS PercentBytes FROM ex040528.log GROUP BY PageType, sc-status
Example (HAVING): SELECT EXTRACT_EXTENSION(cs-uri-stem) AS PageType FROM ex040528.log GROUP BY PageType HAVING PROPSUM(sc-bytes) > 0.1

Truncates a number to a specified number of significant digits, masking the remaining digits to zero.
Example: SELECT time-taken, QNTFLOOR_TO_DIGIT( time-taken, 1 ) AS Dgt1, QNTFLOOR_TO_DIGIT( time-taken, 2 ) AS Dgt2 FROM <1>
Sample output: 17 -> Dgt1: 10, Dgt2: 17 178 -> Dgt1: 100, Dgt2: 170 1789 -> Dgt1: 1000, Dgt2: 1700 17898 -> Dgt1: 10000, Dgt2: 17000 178982 -> Dgt1: 100000, Dgt2: 170000

Rounds a number to a specified number of significant digits, masking the remaining digits to zero.
Example: SELECT time-taken, QNTROUND_TO_DIGIT( time-taken, 1 ) AS Dgt1, QNTROUND_TO_DIGIT( time-taken, 2 ) AS Dgt2 FROM <1>
Sample output: 17 -> Dgt1: 20, Dgt2: 17 178 -> Dgt1: 200, Dgt2: 180 1789 -> Dgt1: 2000, Dgt2: 1800 17898 -> Dgt1: 20000, Dgt2: 18000 178982 -> Dgt1: 200000, Dgt2: 180000

Truncates a value to the nearest multiple of another value.
Example: SELECT time-taken, QUANTIZE( time-taken, 50 ) AS Qnt FROM <1>
Sample output: 15 -> 0 80 -> 50 195 -> 150 205 -> 200 1840 -> 1800
Truncates a value to the nearest multiple of another value.

Truncates a timestamp to the nearest multiple of a number of seconds.
The quantization value is interpreted as seconds.
Example (5-minute intervals, 300 seconds): SELECT TimeGenerated, QUANTIZE( TimeGenerated, 300 ) AS Qnt FROM System
Sample output: 18:48:04 -> 18:45:00 18:51:26 -> 18:50:00 19:33:17 -> 19:30:00

Replaces each occurrence of a character in a given set of characters with a string.
Example: REPLACE_CHR( 'This is a Test', 'is', 'Replace' ) Returns: ThReplaceReplace ReplaceReplace a TeReplacet

Returns the second argument when the first argument is not NULL, and NULL otherwise.
Equivalent to: CASE argument WHEN NULL THEN NULL ELSE replaceValue END
Example (creating a full URL): STRCAT( cs-uri-stem, REPLACE_IF_NOT_NULL( cs-uri-query, STRCAT( '?', cs-uri-query ) ) )

DEPRECATED: Use the COALESCE function instead.
Returns the first argument when it is not NULL, and the second argument otherwise.

Replaces each occurrence of a substring with a string.
Example: REPLACE_STR( 'This is a Test', 'is', 'Replace' ) Returns: ThReplace Replace a Test

Resolves a SID and returns its full account name.
Example: SELECT SID, RESOLVE_SID( SID ) FROM Security
Sample output: S-1-5-18 -> NT AUTHORITY\SYSTEM S-1-5-20 -> NT AUTHORITY\NETWORK SERVICE S-1-5-19 -> NT AUTHORITY\LOCAL SERVICE

Resolves an IP address and returns the corresponding host name.
When the IP address cannot be resolved, returns the IP address itself.
Example: SELECT REVERSEDNS( c-ip ) FROM <1>

Encodes or decodes a string using the ROT13 algorithm.
ROT13 is a weak encryption algorithm commonly used to obfuscate strings.
Example (encode): ROT13( 'This is a test' ) Returns: Guvf vf n grfg
Example (decode): ROT13( 'Guvf vf n grfg' ) Returns: This is a test

Returns the integer closest to the specified argument.
Example: ROUND( 4.9837 ) Returns: 5.000000

Removes whitespace characters from the end of a string.
Example: RTRIM( Comment )

Returns a unique sequential integer associated with the current input record number.
Cannot appear in WHERE, GROUP BY, or HAVING clauses, and cannot be used as an argument to aggregate functions.
Equivalent to: ADD( IN_ROW_NUMBER(), SUB( startValue, 1 ) )
Example: SELECT SourceName, SEQUENCE(1000) FROM System
Sample output: EventLog -> 1000 EventLog -> 1001 Service Control Manager -> 1002

Calculates the square of the specified argument. Return type depends on the type of the argument.
Example: SQR( cs-bytes )

Calculates the square of the specified argument. Return type depends on the type of the argument.
Example: SQR( cs-bytes )

Calculates the square root of the specified argument.
Example: SQRROOT( cs-bytes )

Appends one string to another.
Example (creating a full URL): STRCAT( cs-uri-stem, REPLACE_IF_NOT_NULL( cs-uri-query, STRCAT( '?', cs-uri-query ) ) )

Returns the number of occurrences of a substring in a string.
Example: STRCNT( 'This is a Test', 'is' ) Returns: 2

Returns the length of a string.
Example: SELECT STRLEN( cs-uri-stem ) FROM <1>

Creates a string by repeating a substring a given number of times.
Example: STRREPEAT( 'A', 20 ) Returns: AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA

Reverses the characters in a string.
Example: STRREV( 'This is a test' ) Returns: tset a si sihT
Calculates the difference of two INTEGER values.
Calculates the difference of two REAL values.
Remainder of first STRING argument after removing prefix common to the second STRING argument.

Calculates the difference of two TIMESTAMP values.
Example (last 24 hours from Event Log): SELECT * FROM SYSTEM WHERE TimeWritten > SUB( SYSTEM_TIMESTAMP(), TIMESTAMP('0000-01-02', 'yyyy-MM-dd') )
Date duration reference (epoch is 0000-01-01): 1 day = '0000-01-02' 2 days = '0000-01-03' 7 days = '0000-01-08'

Returns a substring beginning at a specified location and having a specified length. The index of the first character in a string is zero. When the length argument is not specified, the substring continues to the end of the string.

Returns the sum of all values of the specified field-expression. NULL values are ignored.
DISTINCT can only be used without a GROUP BY clause.
Example: SELECT SUM(Size) FROM C:\windows\system32\*.* WHERE TO_LOWERCASE(EXTRACT_EXTENSION(Name)) = 'exe'
Example (with GROUP BY): SELECT TO_LOWERCASE( EXTRACT_EXTENSION(cs-uri-stem)) AS PageType, SUM(sc-bytes) FROM ex031118.log GROUP BY PageType

Returns the sum of all values of the specified field-expression. NULL values are ignored.
DISTINCT can only be used without a GROUP BY clause.

Returns the current system date in Universal Time Coordinates (UTC) time.
Returns a date-only timestamp (year, month, day only).
Example: SELECT * FROM <1> WHERE date < SYSTEM_DATE()

Returns the current system time of the day in Universal Time Coordinates (UTC) time.
Returns a time-only timestamp (hour, minute, second, millisecond, nanosecond only).
Example: SELECT * FROM <1> WHERE date = SYSTEM_DATE() AND time >= QUANTIZE( SYSTEM_TIME(), 3600 )

Returns the current system date and time in Universal Time Coordinates (UTC) time.
Example (local time): SELECT TO_LOCALTIME( SYSTEM_TIMESTAMP() )
Example (events from past two days): SELECT * FROM SYSTEM WHERE TimeGenerated >= TO_LOCALTIME( SUB( SYSTEM_TIMESTAMP(), TIMESTAMP('0000-01-03', 'yyyy-MM-dd') ) )

Returns the current system timezone and daylight saving offset relative to Universal Time Coordinates (UTC) time.
Always returns a positive offset value, even on systems whose time offset is negative with respect to UTC.
Example: TO_STRING( SYSTEM_UTCOFFSET(), 'hh:mm' ) Returns: 08:00

Converts a string to a TIMESTAMP value.
Examples: TIMESTAMP('2026-02-08', 'yyyy-MM-dd') TIMESTAMP('12', 'h') TIMESTAMP('30', 'm')
Duration format for use with ADD/SUB: The epoch is 0000-01-01, so: 1 day = TIMESTAMP('0000-01-02', 'yyyy-MM-dd') 7 days = TIMESTAMP('0000-01-08', 'yyyy-MM-dd')
Note: Hour values must be 0-23. For 24+ hours, use the date format instead. See the Microsoft Log Parser Help topic 'Timestamp Format Specifiers' for more information.

Converts a full timestamp into a date-only timestamp (year, month, day only).
Example (today's events): SELECT * FROM System WHERE TO_DATE( TimeGenerated ) = TO_LOCALTIME( SYSTEM_DATE() )

Returns the hexadecimal representation of an integer.
32-bit values return a DWORD representation. Values exceeding 32-bit return a QWORD representation.
Example (32-bit): TO_HEX( 242 ) Returns: 0x000000F2
Example (64-bit): TO_HEX( 10000000000000000 ) Returns: 0x002386F26FC10000

Returns the hexadecimal representation of the UNICODE characters in a string.
Example: TO_HEX( 'Test' ) Returns: 0x0054006500730074

Converts a value of REAL, STRING, or TIMESTAMP data type into an INTEGER.
REAL: returns the nearest integer. STRING: parses the string (prefix '0x' for hex). TIMESTAMP: returns seconds since midnight, Jan 1, year 0. Returns NULL if conversion fails.
Example (REAL): TO_INT( 5.78 ) -> 6
Example (STRING decimal): TO_INT( '242' ) -> 242
Example (STRING hex): TO_INT( '0xF2' ) -> 242
Example (TIMESTAMP): TO_INT( SYSTEM_TIMESTAMP() ) -> 63268278951

Converts a timestamp from Universal Time Coordinates (UTC) time into local time.
Uses the system timezone and daylight saving offset in effect at the moment represented by the argument.
Example: SELECT * FROM SYSTEM WHERE TimeGenerated >= TO_LOCALTIME( SUB( SYSTEM_TIMESTAMP(), TIMESTAMP('0000-01-03', 'yyyy-MM-dd') ) )

Returns a string where all alphabetic characters have been converted to lowercase.
Example: TO_LOWERCASE( 'Mixed Case String' ) Returns: mixed case string

Converts a value of INTEGER, STRING, or TIMESTAMP data type into a REAL.
INTEGER: returns the same number with no decimal digits. STRING: parses the decimal number from the string. TIMESTAMP: returns seconds since midnight, Jan 1, year 0. Returns NULL if conversion fails.
Example (INTEGER): TO_REAL( 5 ) -> 5.000000
Example (STRING): TO_REAL( '242.789' ) -> 242.789000
Example (TIMESTAMP): TO_REAL( SYSTEM_TIMESTAMP() ) -> 63268280268.011993

Converts an INTEGER or REAL numeric value into a STRING.
Example (INTEGER): TO_STRING( 242 ) -> '242'
Example (REAL): TO_STRING( 242.89 ) -> '242.890000'

Formats a TIMESTAMP value as a string using format specifiers.
Example: TO_STRING( SYSTEM_TIMESTAMP(), 'MMM, ddd yyyy-MM-dd hh:mm:ss.ll' ) Returns: Nov, Sun 2004-11-21 20:01:14.446

Converts a full timestamp into a time-only timestamp (hour, minute, second, millisecond, nanosecond only).
Example (events generated at 2 PM daily): SELECT * FROM System WHERE QUANTIZE( TO_TIME( TimeGenerated ), 3600 ) = TIMESTAMP( '14:00', 'hh:mm' )

Parses a string representing a timestamp and returns a TIMESTAMP value.
Returns NULL if the string cannot be parsed as a valid timestamp.
Example: WHERE TO_TIMESTAMP( MyField, 'yyyy, MM dd hh:mm' ) > SYSTEM_TIMESTAMP()

Returns a string where all alphabetic characters have been converted to uppercase.
Example: TO_UPPERCASE( 'Mixed Case String' ) Returns: MIXED CASE STRING

Converts a timestamp from local time into Universal Time Coordinates (UTC) time.
Uses the system timezone and daylight saving offset in effect at the moment represented by the argument.
Example (events from past two days): SELECT * FROM SYSTEM WHERE TO_UTCTIME( TimeGenerated ) >= SUB( SYSTEM_TIMESTAMP(), TIMESTAMP('0000-01-03', 'yyyy-MM-dd') )

Removes whitespace characters from the beginning and end of a string.
Equivalent to: LTRIM( RTRIM( field ) )
Example: TRIM( Comment )

Converts a string to URL-encoded form suitable for transmission as an HTTP query string.
Codepage values: 0 = system codepage, 65001 = UTF-8 (default), -1 = UNICODE.
Example: URLESCAPE( '/My Test Dir/default.asp?param=Test&Value=%' ) Returns: /My%20Test%20Dir/default.asp?param=Test&Value=%25

Converts a URL-encoded string into its plain, unencoded form.
Codepage values: 0 = system codepage, 65001 = UTF-8 (default), -1 = UNICODE.
Example: URLUNESCAPE( '/My%20Test%20Dir/default.asp?param=Test&Value=%25' ) Returns: /My Test Dir/default.asp?param=Test&Value=%

Returns the text message associated with a numeric Windows error code.
Example: SELECT sc-status, sc-win32-status AS WStatus, WIN32_ERROR_DESCRIPTION( WStatus ) FROM <1>
Sample output: 404, 2 -> The system cannot find the file specified. 404, 64 -> The specified network name is no longer available. 500, 87 -> The parameter is incorrect.
